Software Engineering Project - Course Guide

Projects

Projects catalog

This page explains what a project is in this course, how each brief is structured, what research is expected, and lists the available topics.

On this page

  • What is a project?
  • Structure of each project brief
  • Research expectations
  • How to use this catalog
  • Available projects

What is a project?

A lecturer‑proposed, real‑world topic executed by a team of three. You will investigate unfamiliar technologies, make and defend engineering decisions, and deliver a working, documented, and tested solution. Your Bachelor’s thesis (BAP) runs in parallel to capture rationale, evidence, and reflection.

See also: Project selection and teams, Planning, Coaching.

Code availability and usability requirements

  • Host all project code in a public GitHub repository owned by your team.
  • Deliver a ready‑to‑use artifact (app, library, CLI, or framework).
  • Make installation and deployment a breeze:
    • One‑command setup (e.g., make up, docker compose up, or a single install script).
    • Libraries: publish install instructions via the package manager (e.g., npm/JSR) and include runnable examples.
    • Provide env.example and sensible default configs.
  • Document clearly:
    • README with Quick start, Features, Usage, Configuration, and Troubleshooting.
    • Installation/deployment guide (local and, if relevant, containerized/cloud).
    • Architecture overview and contribution/development notes.
  • Use GitHub as your workflow hub:
    • Commit and push regularly (daily during project weeks).
    • Develop on feature branches;
    • Keep main protected and green (CI on push/PR).
    • Track work with Issues and a project board; link PRs to issues.

These requirements apply to all topics in this catalog.

Documentation Cheatsheet

Minimum files

  • README.md — Quick start, usage, config, tests, architecture link
  • LICENSE — MIT or Apache-2.0
  • .env.example — sample environment variables
  • CHANGELOG.md — notable changes
  • .github/workflows/ci.yml — CI on push/PR
  • src/, tests/ — code and tests

Pull Request checklist@

  • One-command run works on a clean machine
  • README updated (Quick start, Usage, Config, Tests)
  • CI green (lint/test/build)
  • .env.example present, no secrets in repo
  • CHANGELOG.md updated

README sections (order)

  1. Quick start (3 steps, copy-paste commands)
  2. Features (3–6 bullets)
  3. Usage (examples or CLI/API calls)
  4. Configuration (.env keys explained)
  5. Tests (npm test / deno test / go test)
  6. Troubleshooting (2–4 common issues)

CI essentials

  • Trigger on push + PR
  • Steps: checkout → setup runtime → install → lint → test → build
  • Keep lint/build optional via --if-present

Structure of each project brief

Each project page follows a consistent structure so you can compare topics easily:

  • Title
  • Project description
    • Goal
    • Context
    • Desired outcome
      • Functional requirements
      • Non‑functional requirements
  • Project requirements
  • Useful information

This mirrors the course template and the expectations used for grading and deliverables.

Research guideline (for all projects)

Use this step-by-step guideline during your discovery phase. It is based on the selected steps (research question, core concepts, comparison, technology choices, publication/OSS, vision/philosophy, alternatives).

1) Research question or objective

Define the central question and what success looks like.

  • What problem are you solving and for whom?
  • Success criteria: measurable outcomes (e.g., latency < Xs, DX goals, feature scope).
  • Scope: in/out; assumptions and constraints.

Deliverables

  • 1–2 sentence research question.
  • Success criteria and initial scope (bullets).

2) Core concepts to master

List and explain the foundational ideas for your topic.

  • Examples: CQRS; Event Sourcing vs direct updates; Eventual vs Strong consistency; Polyglot persistence; ORM patterns; agent workflows; rendering/reactivity.
  • Add short definitions and links to 1–2 authoritative sources per concept.
  • Optional: tiny spikes/prototypes to verify understanding.

Deliverables

  • Concept notes (bullets + sources).
  • Optional spike results (code snippets/screens).

3) Comparative analysis (existing solutions)

Survey relevant libraries, frameworks, or architectures.

  • Compare on: flexibility, performance, extensibility, reliability, community, docs, licensing.
  • Capture trade‑offs and “lessons learned” that shape your design.
  • Include minimal experiments if feasible (benchmarks, API ergonomics trials).

Deliverables

  • Comparison table + short summary (what you’ll adopt/avoid).
  • Links to references and any micro-benchmarks.

4) Technology platforms & frameworks

Propose candidate stacks and justify the final choice.

  • Candidates across: storage (NoSQL/RDBMS), messaging/event brokers, language/runtime, UI/CLI.
  • Criteria: fit for purpose, complexity, team skills, ecosystem maturity, constraints (licensing, platform limits).
  • Validate with small PoCs (e.g., connectivity, schema evolution, throughput).

Deliverables

  • Evaluation matrix for the chosen stack.
  • PoC notes (scripts, compose file, or minimal code).

5) Publication & open-source strategy

Plan how you will publish, version, and support your work.

  • Public GitHub repository, license (MIT/Apache‑2.0), issue templates.
  • CI/CD: build, lint, test on PR; main stays green; tagged releases; CHANGELOG.
  • Distribution: npm/JSR for libraries, container images or scripts for apps/CLIs.
  • Documentation standard: README (Quick start, Usage, Config, Troubleshooting)

Deliverables

  • Repo scaffold (LICENSE, README, CI workflow, .env.example).
  • Release/publishing checklist (how to cut a release).

6) Vision and design philosophy

Clarify the intent, principles, and non‑goals.

  • Problems solved and unique value; target users and usage scenarios.
  • Guiding principles (simplicity, extensibility, determinism, operability, DX).
  • Non‑functional priorities (reliability, performance, maintainability).

Deliverables

  • Vision note (1 page max) with principles and non‑goals.
  • High‑level architecture sketch (components and flows).

7) Alternatives considered

Record key decisions and rejected options.

  • For each major decision: context, options, criteria, decision, consequences, evidence.
  • link to experiments and comparisons.
